_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At SYSCO Food Services of Minnesota, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

 *  A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
 *  A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
 *  An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
 *  A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
 *  An overview of our emergency response program
 *  An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Our facility is a food distribution warehouse which uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant.  Perishables are kept in the cooler sections.  Frozen food items are kept in the freezer sections.  The anhydrous ammonia we use as a refrigerant is a chemical that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release.

Toxics

Currently, we have approximately 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia on site in our refrigeration system.  Under most conditions, ammonia is a toxic chemical (see Flammables). 

Flammables

Ammonia has an NFPA Fire Hazard Rating of 1 (slight).  In the presence of an ignition source, ammonia is flammable in air at concentrations between 16% and 25%.  Also

, ammonia in combination with lubricating oil may be flammable at lower concentrations, depending on the amount of oil dispersed in the ammonia. 

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us manage effectively the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of this chemical.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenario and at least one alternative release scenario for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:

Worst-case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

Anhydrous ammonia falls under Risk Management Program 3 requirements since our site is also covered by provisions of 29 CFR 1910.119, OSHA's process safety management standard.  Ammonia is regulated a a toxic chemical.  Failure of our largest ammonia vessel would be the worst case scenario for our facility.  Mitigating the potential effects of such a scenario is the location of the receiver inside our building.  In a worst case scenario, approximately 4,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia as a pressurized gas could be released indoors in 10 minutes.   Exhaust fans would move the vapor out of the building.  

To estimate possible offsite consequences of this release, we used the EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance document (May 24, 1996) integrated in RMPlanner v. 2.0 (lookup tables) software developed by ABS Risk & Reliability Division (formerly JBF Associates) of Knoxville, TN.  According to the look-up tables, a 4,000-pound, indoor release could reach receptors 0.81 miles (4,280 feet) from the plant before dispersing enough not to pose a significant hazard (0.14 mg/l or 200 ppm ammonia) to the public.  In 1990, based on the 1990 U.S. Census and LandView III mapping

software from the US Bureau of the Census, approximately  4,200 people lived in Ramsey and Anoka counties within 0.81 miles of our facility.  With new residential developments since 1990, the residential population in 1999 will be higher than the 1990 Census estimate.  Within that distance are unrestricted public parking areas, residences, businesses, a school and the Anoka County airport . Wetlands in the Rice Creek Watershed District also lie within this area.

Alternative Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

The alternative release scenario for our facility is based on a more likely event than the worst case scenario.  We have assumed a relief valve opens (lifts) and the release goes undetected for 10 minutes before employees manually isolate the problem.  Relief valves are piped to a header (pipe) which vents outdoors above the roof.  The potential release of 600 pounds of ammonia gas results in a distance to toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/l or 200 ppm) at 0.19 miles (1,000 feet).  This distance was also determined using the EPA OCA lookup method mentioned in the paragraph above.  There were approximately 790 people living within that distance of our facility according to he 1990 U.S. Census for Anoka and Ramsey counties together with LandView III mapping software from the U.S. Bureau of the Census.  With new residential developments since 1990, the residential population in 1999 will be higher than the 1990 Census estimate.  Within that distance are unrestricted public parking areas, residences, and businesses.   Wetlands in the Rice Creek Watershed District also lie within this area. 

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address reasonable contingency cases.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals as part of our process safety ma

nagement and risk management programs.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

 *  Process safety information
 *  Process hazard analysis
 *  Operating procedures
 *  Training
 *  Mechanical integrity
 *  Management of change
 *  Pre-startup review
 *  Compliance audits
 *  Incident investigation
 *  Employee participation
 *  Hot work permit
 *  Contractors

As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

a.  Scheduled preventive maintenance of our ammonia refrigeration system according to manufacturer recommendations.
b.  Certified training of our ammonia refrigeration personnel
c.  Adoption of a process safety management program [29 CFR 1910.119]
d.  Membership in the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR)

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  

We have not had any reportable incidents or releases within the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent a

nd/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

1.  Coordinating with local fire department and local emergency response team to schedule annual emergency drills.

2.  Enhanced employee awareness training in process safety and risk management program elements.

3.  Addition of an ammonia sensor in relief valve header line.
